Contrails, short for condensation trails, are line-shaped ice clouds formed by aircraft engine exhaust when flying through cold and humid air. They generate a greenhouse effect by absorbing or reflecting back to Earth approximately 33% of emitted outgoing longwave radiation. Contrails account for over half of the climate change resulting from aviation activities. Avoiding contrails and adjusting flight routes could be an inexpensive and effective way to reduce their impact. An accurate, automated, and reliable detection algorithm is required to develop and evaluate contrail avoidance strategies.

Advancements in contrail detection have been limited due to a lack of quality-labeled data. Recently, a large human-labeled Landsat-8 contrails dataset was proposed. Each contrail is carefully labeled with various inputs in various scenes of Landsat-8 satellite imagery. This work benchmarks several popular segmentation models with combinations of different loss functions and encoder backbones. It is the first to apply state-of-the-art segmentation techniques to detect contrails in low-orbit satellite imagery.

Our work can also be used as an open benchmark for contrail segmentation and is available at https://github.com/Kasliwal17/Contrail_Segmentation.

Contrails form when water vapor from the exhaust combines with low ambient temperatures in high-altitude regions. These contrails create an additional blanket of clouds, increasing the heat-trapping effect that contributes to global warming. Although some contrails are short-lived, they can linger for hours, resulting in new contrails created by aircraft flying on the same routes, accumulating and forming a 'contrail cirrus,' which worsens the heat-trapping effect. As a result, contrails have become a significant contributor to global warming caused by the aviation industry.

An effective solution to reduce the effect of contrails is to avoid the regions of the atmosphere that are cold and humid enough to create contrails and to adjust flight routes and slight changes in flight altitudes to reduce air traffic in such regions. This can be a relatively easy solution to prevent contrail formations and their effects, given that a small proportion of aircraft contributes majorly.

Physics-based models, such as CoCIP and APCEMM, simulate contrails' microphysics and radiative transfer effects but suffer from uncertainties in their inputs. These uncertainties result in large errors in contrail RF predictions from such models. Contrail detection work in aerial images can be largely attributed to Mannstein et al., who operated on brightness temperature imagery using a sequence of manually designed convolution and thresholding procedures, followed by recognizing linear linked components. However, no single model has succeeded in achieving both high precision and recall simultaneously.

Apart from this, deep learning models have been used for contrail detection using images from GOES-16 and Himawari-8 satellites. However, no work has been done in over two decades to implement neural network-based segmentation models for contrails detection and Landsat-8 data, except for one work that used Hough Transforms to segment VHRR imagery.

This work explores the potential of deep convolutional nets to identify and segment contrails in satellite imagery. We use popular semantic segmentation models, such as UNet, PSP Net, DeepLab V3, and DeepLab V3+ with different combinations of loss functions and encoders to adjust them accordingly for capturing the intricacies of contrails and achieving a more generalized result. We train these models on the labeled Landsat-8 contrails dataset, which consists of several scenes from the Landsat-8 satellite in which the contrails have been identified and marked as bounding polygons.

The dataset includes Landsat-8 scenes (primarily from 2018 and inside the viewable extent of the GOES-16 satellite), which have been reviewed by human labelers taught to identify and mark the bounding polygon of each contrail in the scene.
